I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The project will modernize prioritized components of the Yovon irrigation and drainage 
(I&D) system. It will increase the capacities of the Agency for Land Reclamation and Irrigation 
(ALRI) and of water users associations (WUAs) for infrastructure management, and increase 
water use efficiency and productivity. Women farmers will be targeted in all activities.1 
 
2.  Impact and outcome. The impact of the project is food security and people’s access to 
good quality nutrition increased. It is aligned with the  National Development Strategy of the 
Republic of Tajikistan for the Period up to 2030. The outcome of the project is climate and disaster 
resilience, water productivity, and income of male and female farmers increased in selected areas 
of the Yovon I&D system. The project will increase climate and disaster resilience, water and 
agricultural productivity, and farmers’ incomes through three outputs.  
 
3.  Output  1:  Climate-  and  disaster-resilient  irrigation  and  drainage  infrastructure 
modernized. This will modernize, main, secondary, and tertiary systems to increase reliability 
and flexibility in irrigation service delivery, comprising (i) modernized and seismic shock-proofed 
main  and  branch  canals  and  associated  structures;  (ii)  provision  of  energy-efficient  pump 
installations;  (iii) erosion  mitigation,  stabilization,  and  reclamation  of  major  gullies;  and 
(iv) upgraded drainage buried pipe and collector ditch system, and modernized buried pipe 
pressurized tertiary irrigation systems with volumetric metering. 
 
4.  Output 2: Climate-adaptive and gender-responsive management and operation of 
irrigation and drainage systems strengthened. This output aims at increased climate and 
disaster resilience by supporting adaptive management and operation of the modern I&D system. 
It will include (i) establishment of a single system management entity to manage irrigation water 
control and remote monitoring systems, and enhancement of farmers’ resilience to climate 
change; (ii) creation of a union of WUAs, with women comprising at least 10% of the leadership, 
to provide improved services to WUAs and farmers; (iii) operationalization of a cashless payment 
system with volumetric metering and asset inventory for the core project area to enable flexible 
on-demand irrigation; (iv) introduction of modern climate-smart agriculture and irrigation practices 
with improved land management and conservation techniques for farmers; and (v) adoption of 
climate-adaptive labor- and water-efficient water application systems for high-value crops to be 
managed by women. 
 
5.  Output  3:  Policy  for  sustainable  management  strengthened.  This  will  include 
(i) development of options for climate-adaptive and sustainable operation and maintenance (O&M) 
funding, including formulation of a revised tariff structure; and (ii) development and adoption of a 
gender strategy for the ALRI and WUAs to strengthen women’s access to land and improve 
female participation in water management. 
 
6.  The proposed project is estimated to cost $35.2 million. Detailed cost estimates by 
expenditure category and by financier are included in the project administration manual.2 
 
 
 
 
1  About 6,700 farmers, of whom 12% are female, will benefit from improved water service delivery, energy savings, 
and application of climate-smart technologies in I&D. 
2  Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2 of the report and 
recommendation of the President).

II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
7.  Tajikistan  has  limited  financial  resources  for  operating  and  maintaining  existing 
infrastructure assets. This is particularly pertinent to water resources infrastructure, specifically 
I&D, which contributes to the agricultural production and rural livelihoods of 73% of Tajikistan’s 
population. Most of the country’s debt is in the form of concessional foreign loans (70% of total 
sovereign debt). The Asian Development Bank (ADB) and other international financing institutions 
are closely engaging with Tajikistan. This is to build capacity and introduce good governance and 
financial management practices to ensure efficient use of public funds and to mobilize additional 
domestic revenues. Promoting projects’ sustainability and addressing immediate coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19) pandemic effects are supported by ADB. This includes ADB’s $50 million 
COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure Support Program grant for Tajikistan, which was 
approved on 18 June 2020 and active until 31 December 2021.3 It is equally important that 
adequate maintenance of water resources infrastructure and underlying financial sustainability 
measures are systematically and adequately addressed. 
 
8.  Addressing the financial sustainability of water resources infrastructure requires a broader 
perspective than the proposed project, which focuses on the modernization and O&M of the 
Yovon I&D system. The technical assistance (TA) addresses the sustainable financing and O&M 
of I&D systems in Tajikistan at the national level and at the ALRI, thereby providing an opportunity 
to address the vicious circle of accruing debts, neglecting O&M, and increasing costs of required 
repairs and modernization. The TA will include experiences gained in the Vakhsh river basin 
under the proposed project and the Pyanj river basin project.4 The TA will provide an opportunity 
to significantly expand the insights gained and benefits developed under the project. 
 
9.  The COVID-19 pandemic is having a severe economic impact on Tajikistan with trade and 
transportation disruptions and falls in remittances and government revenues. According to the 
International Monetary Fund, Tajikistan's debt-to-gross domestic product (GDP) ratio reached to 
48.1.0% in 2020. The International Monetary Fund projects the debt-to-GDP ratio to marginally 
increase  up  to  48.5%  by  2025.5 Tajikistan's  debt  sustainability  depends  on  how  well  the 
government manages its public debt. 
 
10.  The  Government  of  Tajikistan  plans  a  series  of  fiscal  adjustments  as  part  of 
countercyclical fiscal policy, which may reduce budget availability for capital expenditures and 
jeopardize financial sustainability of infrastructure investment due to further reduced budget 
allocation for the management, operation, and maintenance (MOM) of water resources assets. 
MOM allocations are historically insufficient. For example, it was observed in ADB’s Water 
Resources Management in Pyanj River Basin Project that the ALRI could not secure sufficient 
budget for MOM, even after increasing irrigation service fees and its collection rate to nearly 90%.6 
 
11.  For  better  allocation  and  management  of  limited  MOM  funds  and  for  operational 
sustainability  of  key  infrastructure  assets such  as  irrigation  systems, it  is  imperative  (i)  to

implement a robust asset management system (AMS) to prioritize maintenance expenditures and 
(ii)  to  facilitate  preventative  maintenance  and  infrastructure  longevity,  which  includes 
consideration of financial flows. A digital AMS can also identify priority areas for capital allocation 
to minimize recurrent expenditure levels, maximize impact, and improve  budget allocations and 
cost recovery. 
 
12.  AMSs can be profitably piloted in the agriculture, natural resources, and rural development 
sector which accounts for about 22% of GDP and 39% of tax revenues. The bulk of agriculture 
requires irrigation, and the institutions that manage it form a critical foundation.  The ALRI has 
consistently accrued large debts to its suppliers and employees. In 2017, the ALRI’s debt was 
about $12 million. This was mostly for electricity charges and staff salaries. 
   
13.  The ALRI’s maintenance practices are largely reactive, addressing serious problems and 
system failures as they arise, rather than proactive and preventative. This results in rapid system 
deterioration,  shorter  return  periods  for  system  modernization,  and  considerable  losses  in 
productivity. The reactive maintenance and poor state of I&D systems is partly because of 
shortage of funds and the absence of a rational, data-based system to assess asset condition 
and optimize MOM. Modern AMSs are designed specifically to address these needs. 
 
A modern AMS, in conjunction with an asset cost assessment and a finance management system 
(i.e., an asset and financial management system [AFMS]), will help enhance debt sustainability. 
This AFMS will support a shift to efficiency and productivity gains improved MOM resource 
allocation  and  mobilization,  better  rationalization  of  public  expenditures  and  improved 
opportunities for further domestic revenues generation, and other funding of MOM needs. This 
will support overall public financial management and contribute to Tajikistan’s quality of growth.  
 
14.  The TA will help to improve the financial sustainability of the Yovon I&D system and that 
of the ALRI and the selected WUAs of the proposed project. It will contribute to ADB Strategy 
2030 operational priorities 5 (promoting rural development and food security) and 6 (strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity [of the ALRI]). 
 
15.  The TA will build on findings of the Operation and Maintenance Sustainability of Water 
Resources Infrastructure TA project carried out in the Pyanj river basin (footnote 4). The TA will 
also coordinate, to the extent possible, with other efforts to establish AFMS for irrigation projects 
initiated by development partners, the ALRI, and the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
16.  The TA will support management and planning of O&M and financial and institutional 
sustainability of the Yovon I&D system operators and related institutions such as the ALRI and 
WUAs. The TA will have a pilot function at different relevant levels to be expanded or extrapolated 
to other comparable areas and systems in Tajikistan and possibly other Central Asian countries 
with comparable I&D institutional setup, MOM, and financial constraints.  
 
17.  The TA is coordinated with the ALRI and will build on the Pyanj river basin TA (footnote 6) 
and interventions by other major development partners. It will closely cooperate with the Yovon 
I&D main system service provider and WUAs as well as with the appropriate ALRI staff. The TA 
will have two outputs (Table 1).

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,110,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7). The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 1. 
 
19.  The government will provide counterpart support by access to data and information, 
counterpart staff, office accommodation, and other in-kind contributions. The government was 
informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  ADB, through the Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture Division of the Central 
and West Asia Department, will administer the TA. The Ministry of Finance will be the executing 
agency. The ALRI will be the implementing agency and the existing Project Implementation Group 
will  be  the  implementing  unit.  The  TA  consultants  will  also  support  the  overall  project 
implementation, coordinate their activities with the Project Implementation Group, and the project 
implementation consultants on all relevant technical, institutional, and financial issues. The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 2.
